html: PACE loans also get priority over others debts, w/ the taxman serving as debt collector. The PACE lender gets its taste before federal finance agencies or anyone else. No other loan can do this.

html: PACE loans are odd b/c the lender doesn’t have to confirm you make enough money to afford the loan. They just check the value of your home. Can’t come up w/ the money later? That’s OK. You’ll lose your home & the PACE lender will take its cut from the sale price.

html: The First Step Act provides hundreds of new rights and privileges to federal prisoners. More phone time, reduced sentences, “compassionate release,” and early release credits. There is not a single benefit in the bill for the victims of these criminals.
text:
The First Step Act provides hundreds of new rights and privileges to federal prisoners. More phone time, reduced sentences, “compassionate release,” and early release credits.
 
There is not a single benefit in the bill for the victims of these criminals.

html: Opponents falsely claim victim notification amendment wouldn’t allow victims to opt-out of notification. Current law for other notifications doesn’t mention “opt-outs,” but Bureau of Prisons still provides it. This will not change.
text: Opponents falsely claim victim notification amendment wouldn’t allow victims to opt-out of notification. Current law for other notifications doesn’t mention “opt-outs,” but Bureau of Prisons still provides it. This will not change.

html: The amendment I offered with @SenJohnkennedy, cosponsored by Senators Barrasso, Kyl, Sasse, and Toomey, would notify victims before their victimizer is granted early prerelease custody and give victims a chance to make a statement to the warden. I hope my colleagues vote yes.
text:
The amendment I offered with @SenJohnkennedy, cosponsored by Senators Barrasso, Kyl, Sasse, and Toomey, would notify victims before their victimizer is granted early prerelease custody and give victims a chance to make a statement to the warden. 
 
I hope my colleagues vote yes.

html: I'm proud to have @SenJohnKennedy, @SenJohnBarrasso, Senator Kyl, @SenSasse, and @SenToomey as cosponsors for this amendment. We only need 51 votes to make this bill a little better and safer. I urge all my colleagues to support it.

html: Now, please tell me which of the crimes in my amendment should remain eligible for early release time credits. Coercing a child to engage in sexual activity? Assaulting law enforcement? Assaulting a child? Carjacking? Bank robbery? Hate crimes? They should all be made ineligible.
text: Now, please tell me which of the crimes in my amendment should remain eligible for early release time credits. Coercing a child to engage in sexual activity? Assaulting law enforcement? Assaulting a child? Carjacking? Bank robbery? Hate crimes? They should all be made ineligible.

html: Opponents of my amendment continue to push false claim it “would make virtually all federal prisoners ineligible for earned time credits,” so I’m posting analysis from bipartisan US Sentencing Commission confirming 62% of prisoners are still eligible if my amendment‘s adopted:pic.twitter.com/ynwVta0e6E
text: Opponents of my amendment continue to push false claim it “would make virtually all federal prisoners ineligible for earned time credits,” so I’m posting analysis from bipartisan US Sentencing Commission confirming 62% of prisoners are still eligible if my amendment‘s adopted:pic.twitter.com/ynwVta0e6E

html: I also strongly support @jiminhofe's amendment #4141 that would fix the unconstitutional, unfunded mandate in the First Step Act that could bankrupt local jails. This is a serious issue in the bill that has received little attention thus far.
text: I also strongly support @jiminhofe's amendment #4141 that would fix the unconstitutional, unfunded mandate in the First Step Act that could bankrupt local jails. This is a serious issue in the bill that has received little attention thus far.

html: And @SenSasse would also get rid of the section that reduces the penalty for repeat fentanyl trafficking in amendment #4142. Fentanyl traffickers deserve no leniency. I strongly support.
text: And @SenSasse would also get rid of the section that reduces the penalty for repeat fentanyl trafficking in amendment #4142. Fentanyl traffickers deserve no leniency. I strongly support.

html: In amendment #4143, @SenSasse would fix the "productive activities" loophole that allows violent felons to gain early release credits by playing softball. Why do bill authors allow “productive activities” to qualify?
text: In amendment #4143, @SenSasse would fix the "productive activities" loophole that allows violent felons to gain early release credits by playing softball. Why do bill authors allow “productive activities” to qualify?

html: The @SenSasse amendment #4144 deserves support. It bans felons who assault police officers, violent bank robbers, and carjackers from early release. Violent offenders should not be eligible for early release to home confinement or to “supervised release.”
text: The @SenSasse amendment #4144 deserves support. It bans felons who assault police officers, violent bank robbers, and carjackers from early release. Violent offenders should not be eligible for early release to home confinement or to “supervised release.”

html: My colleague @Senorrinhatch has introduced comprehensive mens rea reform in amendment #4137 that I hope will be accepted by my colleagues. Disappointed this was not included in bill.

html: And @SenToomey amendment #4120 would provide more funding for victims of violent crimes. This is an outstanding and much-needed amendment that deserves my colleagues’ support.
text: And @SenToomey amendment #4120 would provide more funding for victims of violent crimes. This is an outstanding and much-needed amendment that deserves my colleagues’ support.

html: I also support @SenToomey amendment #4119 that increases the penalty against violent felons who stalk children.
text: I also support @SenToomey amendment #4119 that increases the penalty against violent felons who stalk children.

text: I am proud to support @SenToomey First Step Act amendment #4118 that would raise the penalty for felons who murder police officers or first responders by ensuring that capital punishment is an option.

html: While I still have concerns with First Step Act, I strongly support and am proud to sponsor @SenatorLankford amendment #4121 to ensure faith-based organizations can work with prisoners to improve lives and reduce recidivism. I urge my colleagues to pass this common sense fix.

html: Proponents of the FSA misleadingly claim my amendment “would make virtually all federal prisoners ineligible for earned time credits.” But the U.S. Sentencing Commission confirms 62% of federal prisoners would remain eligible even if my amendment is adopted.

text: Then, bill creates new "time credits" section, and trafficker can get 10 days credit per 30 spent in "evidence-based recidivism reduction programming or productive activities." 15 days if “low-risk.” This = up to 1/3rd of the sentence, or 5 out of 15 years.pic.twitter.com/4gl4KzJbAo

html: It’s rich for the Russians to protest the U.S.’s refusal to certify one of their planes for the Open Skies Treaty when they routinely restrict surveillance flights over Kaliningrad. The Open Skies Treaty is out of date and favors Russia, and the best way forward is to leave it.

html: Today is the anniversary of the Siege of Bastogne. In Dec. 1944, the Nazis surrounded the 101st Airborne, which was defending the Belgian city of Bastogne. When they demanded the Americans’ surrender, Brig. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe gave his immortal, one-word reply: “Nuts!”
